subject: Re: [junit] US DoD and jUnit
msgSnippet: Yeah. I wasn t real clear in the email. The person in question made that statement and that contributes to my skepticism. He also thought that junit
messageBody:
Yeah. I wasn't real clear in the email. The person in question made that
statement and that contributes to my skepticism. He also thought that junit
"generates" tests. In his defense, it was a long time ago, he's in QA now
and has not coded in a while.



On Tue, Dec 2, 2008 at 2:07 PM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:

> One quick correction: JUnit is not built-in to Java. It is built-in
> to many Java IDE's, and pretty cool.
>
> David Saff
>
> P.S. JUST FOR FUN: Here's informal evidence that someone building
> mil.dod.* packages uses JUnit:
>
>
> http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/cxf-users/200806.mbox/%3C17782928.post@...%3E
>
>
> On Mon, Dec 1, 2008 at 2:03 PM, David McReynolds
> <david.mcreynolds@... <david.mcreynolds%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> > Someone popped up at a meeting this morning and announced that the US
> > DoD does not allow the use of jUnit for unit testing. First, I find
> > that a little hard to swallow given the second statement about junit
> > being the built-in testing generator provided by java (can you say
> > non-sequitor?). Secondly, I cannot corroborate that statement via google.
> >
> > What I need is link to a document that explicitly corroborates or
> > refutes the statement. So far, it looks like the statement is false
> > but I am only using deductive reasoning there.
> >
> >
>
>



--
--
dlm


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
